conclusion: Use the ideal gas law PV = nRT to find the temperature of the gas in state B.
The number of moles n remains the same throughout the process.
The ratio PV/T is constant for an ideal gas.
Convert the temperature of state A to Kelvin: T_A = 300.15 K.
Identify the pressure and volume for states A and B: P_A = 3 x 10^5 Pa, V_A = 2 x 10^-3 m^3; P_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 2 x 10^-3 m^3.
Use the ideal gas law ratio: (P_A V_A)/T_A = (P_B V_B)/T_B.
Substitute the known values into the equation.
The temperature of the gas in state B is approximately 200.1 K.
